results.title: New York University: physical rehabilitation
results.creator_credit: Al Wasserman, Irving Gitlin and CBS Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Search”.
Shows how a paraplegic war veteran learns again to stand, walk, climb stairs, sit in a wheel chair and finally achieve a symbolic goal; getting a cup of water from a cooler by himself. Shows this veteran as the focal point of many new skills and techniques.

results.title: Massachusetts Institute of Technology: automation
results.creator_credit: Henwar Rodakiewicz, Irving Gitlin, CBS TV and Young America Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Search”.
A tour of laboratories pioneering the development of robot machines designed to take over some of the work once performed exclusively by human beings. Includes a digital computer.

results.title: Cornell University: automobile safety research
results.creator_credit: Henwar Rodakiewicz, Irving Gitlin and Young America Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Search”.
Research shows the advisability of using safety belts in passenger cars; how increased safety can result from new designs for instrument panels; the development of new types of padding materials for car interiors; and the benefits of some form of chest protector on steering wheels.

results.title: Working: Soviet style
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Soviet style”.
A look at the Soviet economy in the 1970’s. Examines some of the Industrial developments, investigates output, productivity, the relationships between management and the trade unions, and management and individual workers. Also examines working conditions and salaries in a coal mine, a refrigerator factory, a timber processing complex, and dock workers in Odessa

results.title: School's in, Soviet style
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Martyn Down, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Russian Education”.
Examines the present school system in the Soviet Union. Demonstrates the style of Soviet teaching which is fairly rigid and formal, with the emphasis on teacher dominated instruction and passive pupils, responding only when instructed to do so. A more flexible teaching style was introduced some years ago but was later abandoned. Photographer, Dean Semler; script, Roger Milliss; editor, Martyn Down; sound, George Hart, Howard Spry; commentator, Margaret Throsby.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arch Nicholson, Martyn Down, Tom Manefield and Film Australia

results.title: Politics: Soviet style
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, David Brownlow, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A brief history of politics in Russia prior to the Revolution in 1917, through the leadership of Lenin and Stalin, into the 1970’s. Identifies the Communist Party as the source of ultimate power and attempts to explain party organisation. Photography is by Dean Semler and narration by Margaret Throsby. Suitable for secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arch Nicholson, David Brownlow, Tom Manefield and Film Australia

results.title: The People's music: Soviet style
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Russian Education”.
Contains eleven examples of Soviet citizens engaged in making music. Ranges from kindergarten children in Minst singing and dancing a traditional folk song to the highly respected professional group, the Kuban Cossack Choir and the Veryovka Folk Ensemble. Photographer, Dean Semler; script, Roger Milliss; editor, Martyn Down; sound, George Hart, Howard Spry; commentator, Margaret Throsby.

results.title: People of influence
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, John Abbott, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Soviet style”.
The troika, which governs the lives of all working Russians is illustrated. The film shows the relationship between the Director, the Trade Union chairman and the Party secretary of an enterprise. The Director of the enterprise is shown at a coal mine, supervising his men; the Party Secretary’s influence aids the workers in a gravel washing enterprise; a Trade Union Chairman is seen at work at a refrigerator factory and shows her responsibilities. Cameraman, Dean Semler; editors, Tom Foley, Wayne Le Clos.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arch Nicholson, John Abbott, Tom Manefield and Film Australia

results.title: Farming: Soviet style
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Soviet style”.
Examines the Soviet agricultural system, the collective farms, or Kolkhoz, the State farms, or Sovkhoz and the importance of the agricultural private plot. Credits include: photography by Dean Semler; script by Roger Milliss; edited by Martyn Down; sound by Howard Spry and commentary by Margaret Throsby.
